data.text: Thoughts on Suspension Seatposts for Bikepacking

Thoughts on suspension seatposts?
Kinekt Suspension Seatpost and Stem | Is it right for you? - Bikepacking Alliance

If your last gravel ride left you feeling a bit shaken the Kinect Suspension seatpost and stem might be a game changer for you.

bikepackingalliance.com
I‚Äôve been riding a Redshift Sports system for years. I highly rate it, ridden in Cambodia (where I live) Malaysia and Australia on various bikes from commute to multi day tours.
data.author: Derrick Murray

data.text: I bought a Cane Creek Thudbuster seatpost, used it for a couple of months, and I actually developed worse back problems. It's like it was too bouncy or something. I have had better luck with a traditional spring seatpost. But after I had some back problems with the Thudbuster, I just went to a fixed seatpost and it's been fine.

data.text: Try different elastomers?

data.text: I have the Redshift on my Fargo and a long travel Thudbuster on a hardtail ebike conversion. Don't really notice until I get on another bike without them! Redshift is definitely less "bouncy."
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: Love the suspension stem but never warmed up to the suspension seat post.. tried a couple, my brother loves them.. gets my lower back, just feels unstable I guess and I stay kind of tense
data.author: Jerry Riggle

data.text: Has anyone tried the PNW coast? It's a combined dropper/suspension post with 40mm of suspension and 100-120mm of drop. I'm seriously considering one
data.author: Jon MacKinnon

data.text: Have one on my Surly Ogre. Pretty nice once things get a little spicy. Just a little bit of give on the back end when you start to descent on some bumpy stuff is nice. Along with the dropper is nice.
data.author: Rex Villanueva
Rex Villanueva

data.text: I love mine.
data.author: Matthew Hall

data.text: I‚Äôm running the PNW Coast on my Trexk 520 Grando I absolutely love it. You can read my full review below. It‚Äôs been almost 90 days since I put the PNW Coast seat post on my Grando and I have gone almost 1000 miles in that amount of time. While I haven‚Äôt quite got my seat adjustment dialed in quite yet (mostly evolving physical fitness levels as well as physical changes to my back and legs) the post itself has more than lived up to my hopes and dreams. With 100mm of travel, swinging my leg up and over the top tube with my bike loaded is a breeze while the up stroke of travel puts the seat right where I need it for maximum power and comfort. The upstroke is a little slower than I like at times, but it is super sensitive to the pressure of my bum and adjusts very easily to the Hight I am looking for. Dampening is provided by a dual chamber hydraulic chamber with 40mm of travel which is adjustable by air pressure. PNW recommends 200-300 psi pressures for best performance and mine came shipped with 210 psi (IIRC), which Witt and I desired to leave as is for the time being. I have found this pressure is perfect for my riding style and comfort. I have yet to bottom out the suspension, even when I accidentally hit a mild drop out on the MTB trails. The suspension levels out the washboards very nicely on the gravel roads allowing me to maintain my fast pace without feeling like I‚Äôm out of control. Lastly on the road the post feels just as if I had a solid seat post allowing me to put the power down without feeling like I am riding on a pogo stick. PNW Coast Drop Bar Lever There isn‚Äôt much to say for this lever. It‚Äôs a basic lever designed for drop bars. I opted for the larger 31.8mm so I could mount it on the flats. However they offer a smaller 24.5mm lever kit for installation on the drops. If I had to do it over again, I would probably try setting it up on the drops. I find it a bit awkward to go from the hoods to the flat to adjust the dropper post while trying to bomb a steep decent. Pros- The Coast Suspension Dropper does exactly what it‚Äôs advertised to do, and exceeded my expectations as a suspension seat post with the added benefit of being a dropper post as well. Sturdy construction without compromise of extra weight. Cost (it‚Äôs one of the cheapest suspension seat posts on the market and is relatively in line with middle of the line dropper posts Badging- I personally like the looks of the PNW Tree logo wrapping around the base of the seat post and the top of the Coast Dropper Lever Cons- Heavier compared to a dropper or a suspension seat post slow rebound rate of the upstroke of the dropper mechanism compared to other dropper posts I have tried out on other bikes Requires a suspension pump with gauge to adjust the pressures properly for the suspension chamber. Conclusion: In conclusion, I will say this has been the best modification I have made to the Grand so far. It was definitely worth the money and then some. It has been a game changer for the way I ride and places I adventure to. Overall if you are looking for a good budget friendly seat post that is durable, offers some suspension, is easily adjustable, and is a dropper this is the seat post for you. Who said you can‚Äôt have your cake and eat it too?
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: Love mine. Once you get used to the way it works. Only issue is I use Blackburn Elite seat bag pack and the way it mounts it gets in the way of the pump valve if I need to add firmness. May change seat bag type since I really dont drop while bike packing, only when MTB ing.
